awd_titl_txt: LTREB Renewal: Understanding controls on state-transition on Yellowstone's northern range
awd_abstract_narration:
The extirpation and subsequent reintroduction of the gray wolf to Yellowstone National Park has provided a rare opportunity to understand how predators can change ecosystems. Originally it was thought the loss of wolves would lead to a dramatic increase in the number of elk, which in turn would lead to substantial changes in the willows along the park's streams. It was expected that reintroduction of wolves would cause a rapid restoration of willow communities due declines in elk numbers. However, the first fifteen years of research indicates that the fate of the willow communities is complex, involving interactions among wolves, elk, bison, beavers and available water. This research will focus on how these complex interactions among predators, grazing animals, and local hydrology influence plants on landscapes.  This knowledge forms the scientific foundation for managing rangelands throughout the western United States, and in so doing, enhances human economies throughout the region. The unfolding story of wolves in Yellowstone is of great public interest and will be communicated in the popular media. The researchers will collaborate with park staff in Yellowstone to offer citizen education to four million visitors annually. Data and conclusions will be made easily available to the public, to natural resource managers, and to researchers throughout the United States.  

The extirpation of wolves from Yellowstone National Park at the turn of the century allowed elk populations to increase to levels that degraded vegetation along small streams. Historically abundant willows were eliminated and dam building by beaver ceased. The reintroduction of wolves to Yellowstone National Park in 1995 caused a dramatic decline in the number of elk grazing on the park?s northern range, creating an unusual opportunity to understand how herbivores influence plant communities. It has been hypothesized that effects of wolves on elk caused a rapid restoration of riparian communities by reducing browsing on willows. The research team has conducted a 15-year, manipulative experiment to test this hypothesis and to understand the roles of herbivory and water availability in controlling willow growth. The experiment found little support for the idea that wolves changed the ecosystem by releasing plants from consumption by elk. Instead, availability of water controlled willow response. The experiment showed that the absence of effects of effects of reduced elk numbers on willows on the northern range is explained by the absence of dam building by beaver, an activity that enhances availability of water for willows. Beavers, in turn, need willows for food and dam building materials. Patchy recovery of willows has allowed beaver to return recently to a few small streams. Dams built on these streams, in turn, may accelerate the recovery of willows. Alternatively, consumption of willows by increasingly abundant bison populations may compete with beavers and prevent them from maintaining dams, preventing widespread willow recovery. Researchers will continue their experiment on willow growth, supplementing it with observations on effects of natural beaver dams on willows to understand how effects of wolves, elk, bison, and beavers act to determine the state of the riparian ecosystem. State-of-the-art statistical models will be used to analyze data. Results will have important implications for understanding and managing riparian zones embedded within semi-arid grassland landscapes worldwide.

por.por_cntn:
It is widely believed that the reintroduction of the grey wolf to the northern range of Yellowstone National park caused rapid and dramatic restoration of the Yellowstone ecosystem. This belief can be traced to its promotion popular media, for example the video ?How wolves change rivers? (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ysa5OBhXz-Q) has been viewed over 40 million times. There are also scientific papers making the claim that reductions in numbers of elk and changes in their behavior resulting from predation by wolves has allowed plants like willow, aspen, and cottonwood to grow and reproduce when they could not do so before wolves returned to Yellowstone.
Twenty years of research on willow growth following the reintroduction of wolves revealed these claims are false. They are false because the changes in the ecosystem that occurred when wolves were absent and elk populations reached all time highs were not be quickly reversed by wolf restoration. Notable among these changes was the loss of tall willows from the riparian zones and the coincident loss of dam-building by beaver. Beaver need tall willows for food and materials for building dams? willow stems are the ?rebar? that reinforce mud. Willows need ponds created by beaver to raise water tables because willows require ground water in their root zones to grow. They also need bare soil created by beaver activity to allow their seeds to germinate.
The research team hypothesized that the absence of beaver activity from the small streams of Yellowstone created a self-reinforcing feedback: willows could not grow tall without the ponds created by beaver dams and beaver could not build dams without tall willows. The researchers also hypothesized that  browsing elk and bison remained sufficiently intense to suppress willow growth. To test these ideas, the research team conducted an experiment over two decades where they examined willow growth annually in the fall and spring in response to simulated beaver dams and fences excluding browsing by elk and bison. The experiment included plots with dams and fences, plots with fences and no dams, plots with dams and no fences and control plots experiencing the same conditions that prevailed across the northern range. There would be no differences among these different plots after twenty years of growth if wolves had restored the ecosystem as claimed. There would be no effect of fences because wolves were ?protecting? willows from browsing. There would be no effect of dams because reduced browsing ostensibly caused by wolves was sufficient to allow willows to grow tall.
The results of the experiment were stark. Willows in experimental plots with dams and fences were almost three times taller than willows in the control plots that mimicked the natural conditions on the northern range. Willows in plots with dams and no fences and willows on plots with fences and no dams also grew much taller than willows on controls plots. Willow on control plots averaged less than two inches of growth annually, while average growth of willows on dammed and fenced plots exceed six inches cm per year. These findings compel the conclusion that wolves have had little if any impact on the willow communities on the small streams of Yellowstone's northern range.
These findings have fundamentally important implications for conservation management and policy. Claims of ecosystem restoration resulting from a restoration of the grey wolf to Yellowstone have been used to justify translocation of wolves to their unoccupied, former range all over the world. Our research adds to findings of others that these claims are exaggerated or false. Ideas proven wrong are, of course, the way science moves forward. However, it is difficult if not impossible to correct inaccurate claims promoted in the popular media that wrongly influence conservation management and policy. There are good reasons to restore wolves to food webs, but rapid ecosystem restoration is not among them. The promotion of ecosystem restoration by restoring top predators like wolves suggests there is a ``quick fix'' for losing them from food webs. The research described here shows there is no quick fix. It is clear that maintaining the benefits of predators to ecosystems by preventing their extirpation is likely to be a more successful strategy than trying to restore those benefits after a long absence of predators from the food web.
